articles.headline: UBS Unit Is Said to Be Close to Guilty Plea in Rate-Rigging Scandal
articles.snippet: Under the settlement, a UBS subsidiary in Japan would agree to plead guilty to a criminal charge. The Swiss bank could also face some $1 billion in fines and regulatory sanctions.
articles.abstract: Under the settlement, a UBS subsidiary in Japan would agree to plead guilty to a criminal charge. The Swiss bank could also face some $1 billion in fines and regulatory sanctions.
articles.byline: By Ben Protess and Mark Scott

articles.headline: Rice Ends Bid for Secretary of State, and Fight With G.O.P.
articles.snippet: In withdrawing her name, Susan E. Rice, the ambassador to the United Nations, removed a major source of tension between the White House and Congressional Republicans.
articles.abstract: In withdrawing her name, Susan E. Rice, the ambassador to the United Nations, removed a major source of tension between the White House and Congressional Republicans.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Obama knew before he picked up the phone on Thursday afternoon what Susan E. Rice, his ambassador to the United Nations, was calling about: she wanted to take herself out of the running for secretary of state and spare him a fight.

articles.headline: With Gap Wide and Time Short, Obama and Boehner Meet
articles.snippet: Speaker John A. Boehner and President Obama made no apparent progress in bridging their parties’ differences on taxes and entitlement programs.
articles.abstract: Speaker John A. Boehner and President Obama made no apparent progress in bridging their parties’ differences on taxes and entitlement programs.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — With time running short to work out a deal to avert a year-end fiscal crisis, President Obama called Speaker John A. Boehner to the White House on Thursday evening to try to move talks forward even as pessimism mounted that a broad deal could be struck that bridges the substantial gap between the parties on taxes and entitlements like Medicare.
articles.byline: By Jonathan Weisman and Jackie Calmes

articles.headline: Revenue Rises, Deficit Falls: Fiscal Cliff Gets Credit
articles.snippet: The fact the stock market is up this month, albeit only a little, should remind us that the cliché “investors hate uncertainty” is nonsense.
articles.abstract: The fact the stock market is up this month, albeit only a little, should remind us that the cliché “investors hate uncertainty” is nonsense.
articles.lead_paragraph: Let us pause to give credit where credit is due.

articles.headline: A Fed Focused on the Value of Clarity
articles.snippet: A greater appreciation for the virtues of transparency has been one of the most important shifts in central banking in recent decades.
articles.abstract: A greater appreciation for the virtues of transparency has been one of the most important shifts in central banking in recent decades.

articles.headline: To Gain From Rising Sales, G.M. Redesigns Pickups
articles.snippet: The new versions of the Chevrolet Silverado and GMC Sierra are the first complete redesigns since 2006.
articles.abstract: The new versions of the Chevrolet Silverado and GMC Sierra are the first complete redesigns since 2006.
articles.lead_paragraph: PONTIAC, Mich. — Signs of recovery in the housing and construction industries have given a much-needed lift to the market for full-size pickup trucks, which took a beating during the recession.

articles.headline: High-Tech Factories Built to Be Engines of Innovation
articles.snippet: Companies that keep their research and manufacturing employees close together, where they can share information, might be more innovative than other businesses.
articles.abstract: Companies that keep their research and manufacturing employees close together, where they can share information, might be more innovative than other businesses.
articles.lead_paragraph: SCHENECTADY, N.Y. — The Obama administration has long heralded the potential of American factories to offer good, stable middle-class jobs in an economy that desperately needs them. But experts say there might be another advantage to expanding manufacturing in the United States: a more innovative economy.

articles.headline: In Cairo Crisis, the Poor Find Dashed Hopes
articles.snippet: Away from the protests in the run-up to a referendum Saturday on a constitution, residents of the crumbling Boulaq neighborhood of Cairo have their own reasons to be consumed with the crisis.
articles.abstract: Away from the protests in the run-up to a referendum Saturday on a constitution, residents of the crumbling Boulaq neighborhood of Cairo have their own reasons to be consumed with the crisis.
articles.lead_paragraph: CAIRO — A faded poster of Hosni Mubarak hangs on a wall in a crumbling neighborhood here, reminding residents of an empty pledge to find jobs for young people. Down the street, a campaign banner for his successor, Mohamed Morsi, hangs across the road, a reminder of more recent promises unkept.

articles.headline: Building a Showcase Campus, Using an I.O.U.
articles.snippet: Colleges have gone on a building spree, channeling the movie mantra, “If you build it, they will come.” Now they are $205 billion in debt, with students and taxpayers facing the bill.
articles.abstract: Colleges have gone on a building spree, channeling the movie mantra, “If you build it, they will come.” Now they are $205 billion in debt, with students and taxpayers facing the bill.
articles.lead_paragraph: Some call it the Edifice Complex. Others have named it the Law of More, or the Taj Mahal syndrome.

articles.headline: Tax Plan Is Popular, but Not Quite Fair
articles.snippet: A proposal to limit tax deductions might be politically popular, but it is not the evenhanded approach to closing loopholes it appears to be.
articles.abstract: A proposal to limit tax deductions might be politically popular, but it is not the evenhanded approach to closing loopholes it appears to be.
articles.lead_paragraph: Mitt Romney may have lost in November, but the ghost of the Republican presidential candidate lives on in the debate over tax reform and the fiscal cliff.
